case_name: Bhagwati Saran and Sushila Devi v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 16 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 16 of 1959. Appeal from the judgment and order

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 18, 1958 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 452 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by AYYANGAR, J. on January 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-Having heard the learned Couns

facts.text: Appellants are two: first appellant Bhagwati Saran and second appellant Sushila Devi, related as husband and wife.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are two in number, related to each other as husband and wife. The second appellant-Sushila Devi-

facts.text: Sushila Devi is a Registered Stockholder and proprietor of firm Balwanta Devi Sushila Devi in Sultanpur, Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: is a Registered Stockholder and is stated to be the proprietor of the firm Balwanta Devi Sushila Devi situated in Sultanpur in Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Bhagwati Saran is husband of Sushila Devi and manager of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: and the first appellant Bhagwati Saran, her husband, the manager of the said firm.

facts.text: Report to Judicial Magistrate, Amathi, by officer in charge Police station Sultanpur dated August 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: to start with the report to the Judicial Magistrate, Amathi, by the officer incharge of the Police station, Sultanpur, dated August 20,1955.

facts.text: Bhagwati Saran worked as Karinda in firm Balwanta Devi Sushila Devi, did sales, purchases, issued receipts under his signature.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati Saran used to work as a Karinda in the firm of Balwanta Devi Sushila Devi and had all along been doing sales and purchases at the shop, and also issued receipts under his signatures.

facts.text: Sushila Devi is wife of Bhagwati Saran and proprietor of the firm after Balwanta Devi died.

anchor.surface_text: Shrimati Sushila Devi is the wife of accused Bhagwati Saran and she was the proprietor. Balwanta Devi has died. Hence she alone is the proprietor.

facts.text: Bhagwati Saran sold iron-bars on behalf of firm above control rate.

anchor.surface_text: In the companys of investigation it was also revealed that Bhagwati Saran had from time to time sold some iron-bark on behalf of this firm after receiving price more than the companysol rate,

facts.text: Accused arrested and released on bail.

anchor.surface_text: The accused persons after being arrested were released on bail.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate registered case and issued summons on September 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Magistrate registered the case and issued summons to the accused on September 16, 1955, the case being directed to be called on September 30, 1955.

facts.text: Accused examined under s.364 CrPC on March 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The accused were thereafter examined before the Magistrate under s. 364 of the Criminal Procedure Code on March 23, 1956,

facts.text: Magistrate framed charge on March 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and on the next day the Magistrate framed a charge against them which read as follows

facts.text: Charge: accused sold 11 Cwt. 12 lb. iron bars on 11th January 1952 at rate Rs. 21-13-9 per Cwt. exceeding controlled rate Rs. 21-2-4 per Cwt.

anchor.surface_text: That you between 10th January 1952 and 27th February 1952 in Sultanpur sold 11 Cwt. 12 lb. iron bars on 11th January 1952 ad 3 Cwt. iron bars on 18-2-52 and Cwt. iron bars on 26th February 1952 at the rate of Rs. 21-13-9 per Cwt. though the companysolled rate as numberified in Government of India Gazette dated 1st July 1952 for the companymodity was Rs. 21-2-4 per Cwt.

facts.text: Controlled price notified in Government of India Gazette dated 1st July 1952: Rs. 21-2-4 per Cwt. for the commodity.

anchor.surface_text: though the companysolled rate as numberified in Government of India Gazette dated 1st July 1952 for the companymodity was Rs. 21-2-4 per Cwt. and thus you charged Rs. 1-15-0, Rs. 2-2-3 and Rs. 4-4-6 respectively excess

facts.text: Appellants moved Sessions Judge Sultanpur to revise Magistrate's order framing charges.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants thereupon moved the. Court of the Sessions Judge, Sultanpur, to revise the order of the Magistrate dated March 24, 1956, framing charges against them

facts.text: Sessions Judge referred to High Court recommending quashing charge due to defect in police report under s.11 Act.

anchor.surface_text: he made a reference to the High Court with a recommendation that the charge framed against the appellants be quashed.

facts.text: Single Judge of High Court disagreed with Sessions Judge on s.11, referred cl.11-B ultra vires to Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by a Single Judge of the High Court, who disagreed with the learned Sessions Judge in his view that the report did number satisfy the requirements of s. 11 of the Act.

facts.text: Division Bench rejected argument that cl.11-B violates Art.19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges answered this point against the appellants and the case thereafter came back before the learned Single Judge

facts.text: High Court dismissed reference and directed prosecution to continue.

anchor.surface_text: and dismissed the reference and directed the prosecution to companysue.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is this order of the High Court. of Allahabad that is the subject- matter of appeal number before us. on a certificate granted by that Court.

facts.text: Court held notification valid and within powers of Controller under cl.11-B(1).

issues.text: whether the report of the police officer dated August 20, 1955, contained the facts constituting the offence with which the appellants were charged, as to satisfy the requirements of s. 11 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It would be seen that the only two points in controversy before the High Court were  1  whether the report of the police officer dated August 20, 1955, contained the facts constituting the offence with which the appellants were charged, as to satisfy the requirements of s. 11 of the Act, and  2  whether cl. 11-B of the Control Order, violated the fundamental right to carry on business guaranteed by Art. 19 1   g .

anchor.surface_text: learned Counsel urged before us two points with reference to the notification issued by the Steel Controller fixing the maximum prices at which the several categories of iron and steel could be sold by producers and stockholders. These were  1  that the notification of the Controller dated July 1, 1952, for the contravention of which the appellants were being prosecuted, was ultra vires the rule-making power conferred upon him by cl. 11-B(1) of the Control Order,

issues.text: if, however, the notification was held to be within his power, the same was unconstitutional in that it was discriminatory and violated Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Before the learned Judge, however, a further point was urged, that s. 11-B of the Iron Steel Control of Production and Distribution Order, 1941  which will be referred to hereafter as the Control Order  was itself ultra vires. This further objection was referred to a Division Bench for decision. The point urged before the learned Judges of the Division Bench was that the power to fix prices vested in the Steel Controller by cl. 11-B of the Control Order was unconstitutional, as violative of the right to carry on business guaranteed by Art. 19 1   g  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The notification of the Controller dated July 1, 1952, was ultra vires the rule-making power conferred upon him by cl. 11-B(1) of the Control Order

anchor.surface_text: learned Counsel urged before us two points with reference to the notification issued by the Steel Controller fixing the maximum prices at which the several categories of iron and steel companyld be sold by producers and stockholders. These were  1  that the notification of the Controller dated July 1, 1952, for the companytravention of which the appellants were being prosecuted, was ultra vires the rule-making power conferred upon him by cl. 11-B(1) of the Control Order,

arguments.court_reasoning: Controller within powers; no evidence of non-registered producers; registered stockholders covered in column III; sub-classification permitted

arguments.claim: Producers other than Registered producers were wholly left out by the Controller with the result that no limitation was placed upon the price they could charge

anchor.surface_text: The ground urged in support of the companytention that the numberification by the Controller was number in companyformity with cl. 1 1 -B  1  was this Whereas under cl. 1 1 - B  1  the Controller was directed to fix the maximum prices which companyld be charged by three different classes, viz.,  a  Producers,  b  Stockholders including Controlled stockholders, and  c  Other persons, the impugned ,notification departed from this scheme in two respects  1  The clause companytemplated that the numberification should apply to all producers whereas producers other than Registered producers were wholly left out by the Controller with the result that numberlimitation was placed upon the price they companyld charge,

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence such producers exist; all producers registered

arguments.claim: Registered stockholders had not been specified eo nomine; either outside notification or in residual class, ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: 2  Whereas the clause directed the Controller to include both the types of stockholders Registered as well as Controlled - within the same class and make the same limit of prices applicable to both, the numberification had included only Controlled stockholders as the second category of dealers and registered stockholders had number been specified eo numberine by him. This meant either that Registered stockholders were wholly outside the class of dealers governed by the numberification or that they were intended to be included in the residuary class in companyumn III.

arguments.court_reasoning: Heading of column III includes all other than registered producers and controlled stockholders

arguments.claim: If notification within power, the same was unconstitutional in that it was discriminatory and violated Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: 2  if, however, the numberification was held to be within his power, the same was unconstitutional in that it was discriminatory and violated Art. 14 of the Constitution. As we have indicated earlier, these grounds of challenge to the validity of the numberification were number made in any of the Courts below including the High Court,

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification rational (wholesale-retail analogy); presumption of constitutionality; burden on challenger

arguments.claim: Some of the General Conditions appended to the notification were discriminatory of the class of registered stockholders as compared with the controlled stockholders invoking Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: The argument next advanced in challenge of the validity of the numberification was, that some of the General Conditions appended to the numberification were discriminatory of the class of registered stockholders as companypared with the companytrolled stockholders invoking for this purpose Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: No material to show irrational discrimination; presumption against; requires full facts

arguments.claim: Special conditions on credit facilities and cutting charges discriminatory (afforded to controlled but denied to registered)

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel, however, urged two matters wherein facilities had been afforded or price increases permitted, to companytrolled stockholders which were denied to registered stockholders and that these had been done without any rational basis. These were  1  The 3rd of the special companyditions for sale by companytrolled stockholders read The question of credit facilities will be a matter for negotiation between the customers and the companytrolled stockholders.

arguments.court_reasoning: Differentiation not per se discrimination; no proof of irrationality

arguments.claim: Allowance of credit facilities and cutting charges indeterminate, departed from fixing definite maximum prices

anchor.surface_text: There was a slight and subsidiary point raised in regard to the allowance of credit facilities and cutting charges. It was said that these charges were indeterminate and that the Controller having been directed by cl. 11-B  1  to fix definite maximum prices had departed therefrom by permitting increases of undefined amounts.

arguments.court_reasoning: Incidentals incapable of definite quantification; base price fixed

court_response_anchor.surface_text: directed the prosecution to companytinue. It is this order of the High Court. of Allahabad that is the subject- matter of appeal number before us. on

arguments.claim: Ground regarding the constitutionality of cl. 11-B of the Control Order has been the subject of elaborate consideration by this Court in Union of India v. Messrs. Bhana Mal Oulzari Mal and is, therefore, no longer open to argument

anchor.surface_text: The ground regarding the companystitutionality of el. 11-B of the Control Order has been the subject of elaborate companysideration by this Court in Union of India v. Messrs. Bhana Mal Oulzari Mal  1  and is, therefore, numberlonger open to argument.

arguments.claim: The Controller is not prevented from drawing a distinction within the three classes specified in cl.11-B(1); sub-classification based on rational grounds within power

anchor.surface_text: This apart, we companysider that even on the terms of cl. 11-B  1 , the Controller is number prevented from drawing a distinction within the three classes which are specified in it. The purpose and policy of the enactment is to ensure that an essential companymodity like iron and steel is made available, to the companysumer at reasonable prices and in the achievement of this objective classification of producers or of other stockholders based upon rational grounds would obviously be within the power of the Controller.

arguments.claim: Notification fixing prices together with conditions appended thereto are valid and enforceable

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the numberification fixing the prices together with the companyditions appended thereto are valid and enforceable.

holdings.text: Clause 11-B of the Control Order does not violate the fundamental right to carry on business guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(g), as previously held by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The ground regarding the constitutionality of cl. 11-B of the Control Order has been the subject of elaborate consideration by this Court in Union of India v. Messrs. Bhana Mal Oulzari Mal and is, therefore, no longer open to argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent from Union of India v. Messrs. Bhana Mal Oulzari Mal.

holdings.text: The notification dated July 1, 1952, fixing maximum prices is within the rule-making power conferred by cl. 11-B(1) of the Control Order.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in rejecting the contention of learned Counsel, that the notification of the Controller fixing maximum prices is beyond his power, as not warranted by the terms of cl. 11 -B (1) of the Control Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Controller empowered to sub-classify producers/stockholders on rational grounds; no evidence of unregistered producers; column III covers registered stockholders.

holdings.text: The notification and appended conditions do not discriminate against registered stockholders and do not violate Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that there is no material on the basis of which an argument could be sustained that the special conditions to which learned Counsel adverted contained any element of unfair or irrational discrimination to attract Art. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification rational (e.g., controlled vs. registered akin to wholesaler-retailer); presumption of constitutionality; no proof of irrationality; differentiation not per se discrimination.

holdings.text: The notification fixing prices together with conditions appended thereto are valid and enforceable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizes rejection of ultra vires and Art.14 challenges; incidentals like credit/cutting charges allowable as incapable of precise fixation.

holdings.text: The police report dated August 20, 1955, satisfies the requirements of s.11 of the Act as it contains facts constituting the offence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the High Court rejected this contention and, in our opinion, correctly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report identifies contravened provision, status as registered stockholders, sales above notified price; details like dates/quantities for trial/charge stage; purpose prevents private prosecutions.

holdings.text: Allowing additional grounds challenging notification validity exceptionally, as prosecution pending and based on record.

anchor.surface_text: If in the appeal now before us, we have departed from this rule, and permitted the appellants to urge the additional grounds it was because of the circumstance that the prosecution was pending...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exceptional departure from rule limiting appeals to High Court grounds, due to pending prosecution and materials on record.
